importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article marks the outbreak of renewed cross-border violence between Afghanistan and Pakistan, breaking a 48-hour ceasefire and reigniting tensions that had previously been subdued.
The truce began on October 16, 2025, and was intended to provide two days of relative calm after a week of intense border clashes, highlighting the timing and fragility of peace efforts.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The 48-hour ceasefire that began on October 16, 2025, was broken on October 18, 2025, marking a critical turning point in cross-border hostilities between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan launched air attacks inside Afghanistan, killing at least 10 civilians and wounding 12, including two children, in Paktika province.
The attacks broke a 48-hour ceasefire that had brought temporary calm after a week of deadly border clashes.

Afghan officials accuse Pakistan of targeting the Hafiz Gul Bahadur Group, a faction linked to the Pakistan Taliban (TTP), following a suicide bombing that killed seven Pakistani paramilitary troops in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas.

The Afghanistan Cricket Board claimed three cricketers and five others were killed in an attack during a homecoming gathering in Urgun district, calling it a 'cowardly attack' by the Pakistani regime.
Afghanistan has withdrawn from the upcoming Tri-Nation T20I Series involving Pakistan, scheduled for next month.

Afghan and Pakistani officials are set to hold crisis talks in Doha, with Afghan Defence Minister Mullah Muhammad Yaqoob and Pakistani Defence Minister Khawaja Asif and Intelligence Chief General Asim Malik participating.
The United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan reported 37 deaths and 425 injuries on the Afghan side of the border during the violent period prior to the latest attacks.
Residents in Spin Boldak expressed mixed feelings, with some fearing renewed violence and others reporting normalcy, indicating ongoing uncertainty and trauma in border regions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Afghanistan accuses Pakistan of breaking a 48-hour ceasefire by launching air attacks in Paktika province, killing at least 10 civilians including two children and injuring 12 others. The attacks target the Hafiz Gul Bahadur Group, a faction linked to the Pakistan Taliban (TTP), following a suicide bombing in Pakistan’s FATA region that killed seven paramilitary troops. The Afghanistan Cricket Board blames the Pakistani regime for killing three cricketers and five others during a homecoming gathering in Urgun district, leading to the withdrawal from a scheduled T20I series. Both sides are now preparing for crisis talks in Doha, with Afghan Defense Minister Mullah Muhammad Yaqoob and Pakistani Defense Minister Khawaja Asif and Intelligence Chief General Asim Malik attending. The UN reports 37 deaths and 425 injuries on the Afghan side of the border during the period of violence. The conflict underscores deep-rooted security tensions between the two nations, with accusations of mutual harboring of armed groups and fears of renewed bloodshed.
title: Afghanistan accuses Pakistan of breaking truce as 10 killed in air attacks
